question.title: Will any state actor use chemical weapons in Ukraine before May 1, 2026?
question.description:
Chemical weapons are defined in line with the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC). Importantly, this category is not limited to Cold War–era nerve agents. Under the CWC, even riot control agents (e.g., CS “tear gas”) may qualify as chemical weapons if used as a method of warfare, rather than for domestic law-enforcement purposes.

OPCW overview:
[https://www.opcw.org/](https://www.opcw.org/)

Chemical Weapons Convention text:
[https://www.opcw.org/chemical-weapons-convention](https://www.opcw.org/chemical-weapons-convention)

So what?

Use of chemical weapons would represent a major escalation of the conflict and a serious violation of international law. Such use could trigger new sanctions, diplomatic escalation, changes in military assistance, and heightened involvement by international institutions. NATO officials have repeatedly warned that the use of chemical weapons in Ukraine would carry severe consequences.

Because attribution and verification are difficult in active conflict zones, official statements—rather than forensic certainty available to the public—play an outsized role in shaping international responses. As a result, the question focuses on whether an official determination or accusation is made, not on whether the allegation is ultimately proven beyond dispute.

What’s happened so far (context for forecasters)

Since the start of the war, allegations of chemical weapons use in Ukraine have been recurrent. Ukraine and some Western governments have accused Russia of using toxic chemicals, including riot control agents and choking agents, while Russia has issued counter-accusations.

The OPCW has conducted Technical Assistance Visits (TAVs) in response to Ukrainian requests and has published official statements and reports describing findings related to alleged chemical incidents. Some OPCW reporting has confirmed the presence of toxic chemicals consistent with riot control agents in certain samples, while noting limits on attribution depending on mandate.

OPCW Ukraine-related materials:
[https://www.opcw.org/media-centre/news](https://www.opcw.org/media-centre/news)

[https://www.opcw.org/resources/documents](https://www.opcw.org/resources/documents)

In parallel, NATO member states have at times publicly accused Russia of chemical weapons use in Ukraine, including allegations involving substances such as chloropicrin or the use of riot control agents in combat settings.

question.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as Yes if, after the opening of this question and before May 1, 2026, a state actor intentionally uses chemical weapons anywhere within the pre-2014 land territory of Ukraine. The question resolves according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) such as accusations from a NATO member state or from the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons ([OPCW](https://www.opcw.org/)).
question.fine_print:
"State actor" is defined as a government of any [sovereign](https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/sovereignty) state, including its armed forces, security services, or other personnel acting in an official capacity. Only confirmed use of chemical weapons (as defined by the Chemical Weapons Convention) counts. 

"Chemical weapon" means a chemical listed at OPCW's [Annex on Chemicals Schedule 1](https://www.opcw.org/chemical-weapons-convention/annexes/annex-chemicals/schedule-1).
